{{out of date|date=October 2011}} {{update|date=October 2011}} {{Infobox national football team| Name = Canada | Badge = Csa logo.png | Nickname = | Association = [[Canadian Soccer Association]] | Coach = {{Flagicon|England}} [[John Herdman]] | Most caps = [[Christine Sinclair]] (167) | Top scorer = [[Christine Sinclair]] (119) | FIFA Rank = 9 | FIFA max = 6 | FIFA max date = March 2011 | FIFA min = 13 | FIFA min date = December 2005 | | pattern_la1 = | pattern_b1 = _canada11h | pattern_ra1 = | leftarm1 = FF0000 | body1 = FF0000 | rightarm1 = FF0000 | shorts1 = FF0000 | socks1 = FF0000 | pattern_la2 = | pattern_b2 = _canada11a | pattern_ra2 = | leftarm2 = fff | body2 = fff | rightarm2 = fff | shorts2 = fff | socks2 = fff | First game = {{fbw|USA}} 2 â 0 {{fbw-rt|CAN}}

([[Honefoss]], [[Norway]]; June 19, 2001)| World cup apps = 4 | World cup first = 1995 | World cup best = 4th place, [[FIFA Women's World Cup 2003|2003]] | Olympic apps = 1 | Olympic first = 2008| Olympic best = Quarterfinals, 2008 | Algarve cup apps = 4 | Algarve cup first = 2000 | Algarve cup best = 4th place, 2001 | Regional name = [[CONCACAF Women's Gold Cup|CONCACAF Women's Championship and Women's Gold Cup]] | Regional cup apps = 8 | Regional cup first = [[1991 CONCACAF Women's Championship|1991]] | Regional cup best = Winners, [[1998 CONCACAF Women's Championship|1998]], [[2010 CONCACAF Women's Gold Cup|2010]] | type=women }} The '''[[Canada]] women's national [[football (soccer)|soccer]] team''' is overseen by the [[Canadian Soccer Association]]. The team reached its all-time high of 6th in the March 2011 rankings. The team reached international prominence finishing in 4th place at the [[FIFA Women's World Cup 2003]], losing to their archrival [[United States women's national soccer team|American team]] in the bronze medal match. The women's game is quite popular in Canada due to the success the team has had internationally.{{Citation needed|date=February 2007}} The Under-20 women's team (U-19 prior to 2006) is also very popular, due partly to Canada hosting the inaugural [[FIFA U-20 Women's World Championship|FIFA U-19 Women's World Championship]] in 2002 and winning silver in front of 47,784 fans at [[Commonwealth Stadium (Edmonton)|Commonwealth Stadium]] in [[Edmonton, Alberta]]. In the first two women's world youth championships, both with an age limit of 19 as opposed to today's 20, the [[Golden Boot]] winner was a Canadian: [[Christine Sinclair]] in 2002 and [[Brittany Timko]] in 2004. Sinclair also won the 2002 Golden Ball as tournament MVP. In 2008, Canada qualified for its first ever Olympic women's football tournament, and finished second in their group with a 1â1â1 record. This was good enough to qualify them for the knockout stage, where they lost to the number one team in the world, the [[United States women's national soccer team|United States]] in the quarterfinals. In 2010, Canada defeated [[Mexico women's national football team|Mexico]] for the second time in six days to win the [[2010 CONCACAF Women's Gold Cup|CONCACAF Womenâs World Cup Qualifier championship]] on Monday 8 November in CancÃºn, Mexico. Canadian captain [[Christine Sinclair|Christine Sinclairâs]] sixth goal of the tournament in the 54th minute was enough to lead Canada to a 1:0 victory. The win capped an impressive tournament for the Canadian squad who finished undefeated with a 5â0â0 record; tallying 17 goals while conceding zero in the process and booking their place at the [[FIFA Women's World Cup 2011|FIFA Womenâs World Cup Germany 2011]]. Canada, whose only previous CONCACAF womenâs title came in [[1998 CONCACAF Women's Championship|1998]], when the US did not participate, were left to celebrate arguably the greatest achievement of their history. However, they were unable to continue their success at the 2011 World Cup as they crashed out of the tournament with 3 consecutive losses. In March 2011, Canada was approved as the host of the [[2015 FIFA Women's World Cup]] after Zimbabwe withdrew their bid leaving Canada as the sole
